author: Akash Bhatnagar
title: World Animal Day 2024| Wamiqa Gabbi: Animals teach us the art of letting go - Hindustan Times
text: A proud mother of six dogs, actor Wamiqa Gabbi shares a unique bond with animals and on World Animal Day today, she opens up on her equation with the four-legged beings. â€œI used to be a non-vegetarian but turned vegetarian over four years ago. The only regret I have is why I didn't do it sooner. The connection I feel with animals now is way more than what I felt a few years ago,â€ she says.Having six dogs at homeâ€”Phoebe, Milli, Julie, Fluki, Gabbar and Momoâ€”who she rescued and adopted during the pandemic, Gabbi insists she creates cherished memories with them every day. â€œMomo was the latest entry in our family and I rescued and adopted him during the shoot of Fursat (2023). There was this two-week-old puppy who was injured and couldn't drink her mother's milk. I saw that she would die, so I picked her up and brought her home,â€ she recalls, adding that going to Masai Mara National Reserve remains one of her most memorable experiences. â€œThere were so many different animals like cheetahs, lions, elephants, giraffes, various kinds of cows, and I was just silently watching them. It was just beautiful,â€ she shares.Ask the 31-year-old what makes animals better companions and she says, â€œI don't know about that, but I definitely find them better than humans as we have somewhere lost our innocence. Animals still possess that innocence and live with it, and I love that. I learn that from them and try to keep it alive in me every day.â€ The actor also admits learning how to forgive and forget from animals: â€œIt doesn't matter if you have shouted at them or they have done a mistake, they won't hurt you in any way. The next time you call them, they will come back to you with as much love. It's such an impactful message that they teach you about letting go, forgiving and forgetting. All they want to do is love you and I just wish humans could understand that.â€Being an animal lover, Gabbi feels hurt when she sees atrocities against animals, and calls for stringent action. â€œSince childhood, we have been taught to love and be kind and respectful. But as we grew up, we forgot all those important teachings. How would you feel if you saw a video of someone beating a child? That's how I feel when I see videos of humans' bad behaviour towards animals. India is a secular country, and I am sure none of the religions teach us to be violent towards animals,â€ she asserts, calling out the need for stronger laws: â€œIf you don't consider violence against animals a crime, that's dangerous. If somebody can kill, beat or molest an innocent animal, how can you trust that person to be safer in our society or around children?â€The actor requests people to just â€œlove animalsâ€. â€œOnce you have love, you will automatically give them food, shelter during rain and clothes during winters,â€ she says, admitting that she hopes to have an animal farm in future one day. â€œAn image that keeps coming to me is that if I have an animal farm, I want to sleep with my head on a cow's tummy. That's an experience I really want to have in my life,â€ she ends.

author: Faith Fernandez
title: Holy Family Kindergartners Visit the Fraternity Poor of Jesus Christ LA Religious Community
text:
Read Previous Post
Holy Family Kindergartners Visit the Fraternity Poor of Jesus Christ LA Religious Community
Recently, Holy Family School (HFS) Kindergarten students meet with Friar Michael and Friar Lucaelo of the Fraternity Poor of Jesus Christ LA religious community to learn about their ministry. This month, the Little Kinder Knights put the Virtue of Generosity into action by making over 200 sandwiches for the Friars ministry to be distributed to those in need.
At Holy Family, students learn that as disciples of Jesus Christ, GENEROSITY comes from the heart, so it is not how big the gift is that matters, but rather the value it has to the person who gave it. Christ lived it. He was always giving of his time, listening, and helping others.
â€œDuring this season of Advent and Christmas, as everyone prepare for the birth of the Lord, HFS remind its students to be thankful for all the beautiful gifts God has given us and, in turn, to give to those less fortunate. To enjoy the time we are blessed with when gathering with family and friendsâ€.
If you would like to learn more about the Poor of Jesus Christ LA religious community, visit
https://pjcfriars.org.
Holy Family Catholic School instills Christian values and Catholic principles in students through the Gospel message of Jesus Christ; Faith, Community, Service and Excellence.
Holy Family School, 1301 Rollin St., South Pasadena, (626) 799-4354 or visit
school.holyfamily.org.

title: Author A.J. Fredaâ€™s New Book, â€œThe Purple Rose,â€ is a Heart-Pounding Novel That Follows a Nurse Who Joins the Fight for the War Effort in the Philippines During WWII - PR.com
text:
Neptune City, NJ, May 03, 2024 --( PR.com )-- A.J. Freda, a retired police officer and lover of military history who served on two destroyers during the Cuban Missile Crisis and holds a criminal justice degree, has completed his new book, â€œThe Purple Roseâ€: a gripping wartime novel that centers around Rosie Favor, a nurse who is sent to the Philippines and rises to the occasion to take on risk and join the fight in service of others.
Freda shares, â€œWhat is the meaning of the purple rose? It is more than a lovely flower that adds beauty to the world. Rare in nature, the flower is incredibly unique, much like the main character in this story, Rosie Favor. The qualities that make Rosie so special are her love of people and her hatred of oppression. She is inspired to take incredible action and personal risks in numerous conflicts to benefit freedom-loving people. This character is given the code name Purple Rose because she is as rare in nature as the flower itself. Motivated by her loathing of the Japanese war machine, this beautiful nurse will be transformed into the Mata Hari of the Second World War.
â€œAs you turn the pages of this book and journey with Rosie as she faces each conflict, you will discover her many talents layered like the petals of a rose, unassuming in beauty and deep in humility.â€
Published by Newman Springs Publishing, A.J. Fredaâ€™s enthralling tale will transport readers as they discover Rosieâ€™s incredible courage and sacrifice, leaving them spellbound as she finds herself taking on greater risk and danger. Expertly paced and full of suspense, Freda weaves a stunningly human and heartfelt story that is sure to resonate with readers from all walks of life, remaining with them long after its shocking conclusion.
Readers who wish to experience this inspiring work can purchase â€œThe Purple Roseâ€ at bookstores everywhere, or online at the Apple iBooks Store, Amazon, or Barnes and Noble.
For additional information or media inquiries, contact Newman Springs Publishing at 732-243-8512.
About Newman Springs Publishing:
Newman Springs Publishing is a full-service publishing house for serious authors. Each title produced by Newman Springs Publishing undergoes every step of the professional publishing process, including editing, layout, cover design, circulation, distribution, and publicity. All titles are made available in both eBook and print formats. Newman Springs Publishing distributes to tens of thousands of retail outlets throughout North America and internationally. All manuscripts in any genre are welcome to be submitted for review; If the manuscript meets the necessary criteria and is accepted for publication, Newman Springs Publishing will work closely with the author to bring the book to the retail market for a relatively inexpensive initial investment.

author: Anna Kutz
title: Photos: Missing California hiker located safely in Big Basin State Park
text:
( NewsNation ) â€” Nine days after a hike gone wrong, 34-year-old Lukas McClish was found safe in Californiaâ€™s Big Basin State Park and reunited with his family. One photographer captured it all.
Emergency rescue photographer Steve Kuehl was on the scene when responding agencies located McClish after more than a week of searching.
â€œIt was obviously a very emotional and raw moment for everybody. Because at that moment, all the responders that were there got to see a mother seeing her son alive for the first time in almost weeks, not knowing what happened to them,â€ Kuehl said. â€œSo it was a powerful moment.â€
Missing hiker rescued after nine days in California forest Kuehl has known McClishâ€™s family for years and witnessed how his disappearance impacted his loved ones.
â€œHis fatherâ€™s a retired fire chief from the local districts, and he pretty much never stopped hiking from what I heard,â€ he said. â€œHe had been up for days, hiking for days, looking in all parts of that area and around our district.â€

Your Morning Newsletter Submit While fire damage changed the landscape of the park and wiped away markers McClish had grown familiar with, leading to his disappearance, fires are also what helped save him.
The man who called and reported McClishâ€™s yelling â€” the â€œunsung heroâ€ of the incident, according to Kuehl â€” was a retired firefighter with a good ear.
Search for Wisconsin 3-year-old Elijah Vue nears four months â€œ[His] house burned down and CZU fire that came through here about four years ago,â€ Kuehl said. â€œAnd with all the foliage removed in the canyon below his house, he was able to hear Lucas calling for help.â€
Rescuing agencies said McClish had no major injuries when he was found.

author: Gabrielle Chung
title: Brigitte Macron Breaks Royal Protocol During Meeting With Queen Camila
text: French President Emmanuel Macron's wife Brigitte Macron accidentally broke royal protocol when she tried to hold Queen Camilla's hand during a memorial service in France."/

author: Staff Report
title: Four arrested for disrupting Christmas Eve church service in Seneca County
text: The Seneca County Sheriffâ€™s Office has reported the arrest of four individuals following an incident on Christmas Eve at a local church in Varick. The incident occurred around 5:58 p.m. when Christopher A. Avila, Jeremy S. Mathias, Daniel J. Watson, and Nathan J. Jackson allegedly trespassed and disrupted a church service on Ernsberger Road by voicing negative comments about Christianity. The deputies responded promptly to the report apprehending the suspects at approximately 6:51 p.m. without any further incident. Upon investigation, all four suspects were charged with disruption of religious service, conspiracy, and trespassing. They were taken to the Seneca County Law Enforcement Center for processing. The arrest operation involved collaboration between the Seneca County Sheriffâ€™s Office, New York State Police, and Waterloo Police Department. The accused have been released on appearance tickets and are scheduled to appear at the Varick Town Court at a later date to address the charges.
